content:
Nice, original clash.

There is a small ambiguity that's not clarified with the duplicated vowel clause, though. It's not clear whether the statement cares only about vowels that are duplicated in a row as with the two "u"s and two "a"s in Luhucianna, or just general duplication like "Luhiciuanna".

Your code shows that this second example would also be treated "MEAN" because the unique set of vowels are in the order "UIA", regardless of them going "UIIUAA" or "UIUA" when removing consecutive duplicates.

It's a small thing, but just thought I'd mention it if you felt it was worth making a bit more clear. "Julianna-Pauli" could be an example that shows that it's not just consecutive repetitions that are ignored, but basically all repetitions of previously seen vowels.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: String manipulation exercice not so hard but good for clash.
Also original background story, I'm glad Julian does not hate me.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good for clash.  
I particularly like that it has a funny premise.  (I think we all know a Mean Julian)

I like it ; very imaginative.  I hope Mean Julian is not someone you have to deal with in real life.

But I feel like the Goal part is not clear enough, when stating what a match would be.  I only understood after I failed Test 5

The way I read it (including how I read your 3 examples) is that you hope the vowels in the name aren't uia (in that order)
I would not have thought that (for example) you would consider something like "Muuxuiiala" a match.

Suggest you put an 4th example such as Lucianna and play with the phrasing to explain a bit better.
Fun clash and quite easy to solve using regex...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a good exercise for string manipulation. The fact to keep unique string values is also very insightful.

Goal section
* Please fix the typo: "does't" should be spelled as "doesn't".

Output section
* Please format "[[n]] lines" as bold (similar to Input section).

Constraints section
* I think you mean ≤ instead of <.

Thanks.

I'm glad you liked the problem! 
Thanks for your review! You're right, I'll add an example to explain this edge case ;)

Suggest:
Change
"Even if there some vowels are duplicated"
to
"Even if some vowels are duplicated"
or
"Even if there are some vowels duplicated"
